awd_titl_txt: Phase II IUCRC University of Mississippi: Center for Broadband Wireless Access and Applications (BWAC)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is Phase II of the Broadband Wireless Access Center (BWAC), a multi-university multi-industry organization composed of five universities (the University of Arizona, Virginia Tech, University of Notre Dame, University of Mississippi (UM), and the Catholic University of America) and 20+ affiliates from industry and government. In the past decade, wireless communications has made major technological leaps. Wireless connectivity is pervasive in society, leading to a shortage in wireless spectrum, network congestion, cyber-attacks and personal security issues. The mission of BWAC is to address these challenges and offer creative solutions. 

This project will bring to bear UM research capabilities and real-world industry interest in several BWAC thrust areas. Center as a whole addresses research areas, including wireless spectrum sharing, security, and future milli-meter wave technology. UM research problems address spectrum sharing for heterogeneous wireless systems, network optimization to mitigate mutual interference in BLE (low energy Bluetooth) and WiFi systems, and 3 D printing of antennas and the design and fabrication of closely spaced antennas and antenna arrays using elliptical metasurface cloaking. Collaboration with industries in the Southeastern U.S. will provide for our students additional co-op and internship opportunities. 

The results of this collaborative industry-university center will have a direct effect on public well-fare, enabling several applications such as remote health and broadband access in rural areas. The partnering universities will broaden their activities to include REU site programs, RET program, participation of under-represented minority students and faculty in research projects, and involvement of multidisciplinary projects. New curriculum at UM will have courses on Internet of Things (IoT) systems and cognitive radios. With its research, established partnerships, and long history of collaboration between its members, BWAC will likely create intellectual property and spin-off companies, leading to job growth. 

The lead site, University of Arizona manages the central BWAC project website at www.bwac.arizona.edu. This website contains various information about the center including the overview of the center, mission, industry membership, projects, meeting announcements and technical data. Center proprietary documents are managed through a secure internal pages requiring access credentials.  The data repository will be managed at the main website with links to the other university sites. The repository will contain technical papers, project descriptions, relevant software, testbed details, etc. The repository will be maintained during the project and for an additional five years beyond its termination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to conduct company-driven research in broadband wireless access and applications and disseminate the findings to the technical community. Pursued focus areas included metamaterials and antennas, additive manufacturing methods for antennas and RF devices, the coexistence of WiFi and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) enabled systems in factory environments, and joint analog distributed detection and communications in sensor networks.

The intellectual merits of the project lie in the technological advancements achieved through optimal designs and implementation across various aspects of wireless communications. The objective of antenna cloaking project was to explore the operational principles and underlying phenomena behind metasurface cloaks for the purpose of cloaking and decoupling closely spaced antennas and overlapping planar phased antenna arrays. Simulation and theoretical results confirm the effectiveness of metasurface cloaks involving both discrete antennas and phased array antennas. Results are expected to be useful for next generation wireless systems for both commercial and military applications. The objective of 3-D printing RF devices and antennas was to investigate the characteristics of printed devices that have been fabricated using 3D printers. A range of printers were used, from filament only to print substrates to filament and conductive ink printers to print entire microstrips. Insight gained by 3D printing into the role infill rate plays in the variation of permittivity led to development of a volumetric infill-rate simulation model that yields the variation of permittivity, which will be useful in antenna design. WiFi/BLE project focuses on developing analytical and simulation tools to guide parameter selection and performance analysis of BLE-based scanning systems in the presence of WiFi and other industrial RF interference. Students designed experiments and wrote programs to manage real-time advertisement and scanning processes and collect and analyze data. Simulation showed that analytical modeling yielded highly accurate average performance estimates but also substantially underestimated the required scanning times due to unexpected correlation in the collision process. The objective of joint analog distributed detection and communications in sensor networks is to determine the optimal transform for sensor observations, subject to the transmission power and bandwidth constraints. A parametric method has been studied, which has demonstrated better performance at the fusion center than the untransformed detection system. The analog detection and communication system could lead to better accuracy, robustness, and low-latency detection critical to tasks of Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR).

The broader impacts of the project are workforce development and outreach. Through their involvement in the projects, five undergraduates,  six MS students, and six Ph.D. students gained valuable research expertise. Among them, one undergraduate student and three MS students were hired by our member companies upon graduation. One Ph.D. student secured a tenure-track assistant professor position at West Texas A&M University. All six MS students have graduated, three Ph.D. students have completed their degrees, and the remaining three Ph.D. students continued to work towards Ph.D. degrees. Research findings from the antenna cloaking project and the 3-D printing of antenna project were incorporated into senior-level undergraduate elective and design courses. Two UG students gained research experience by programming USRPs using GNU radio. More than twenty journals or juried conference papers have been published and disseminated to the research community.
